author: cobalthex
body:
# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
$m = Mount-DiskImage -ImagePath (Resolve-Path '.\test.iso')
Set-Location -LiteralPath $m.DevicePath
```

# Expected behavior
cd into the device path folder

# Actual behavior
```
Set-Location : Cannot find path '\\.\CDROM0' because it does not exist.
````
# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none

```

comments.author: lukeb1961
comments.body:
wouldn't you just refer to the drive? It's a volume, not a device.
$drive = ($m | Get-Volume).DriveLetter + ':'
Set-Location $drive

comments.author: cobalthex
comments.body: Seems roundabout, and is not portable

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
> wouldn't you just refer to the drive? It's a volume, not a device.
> $drive = ($m | Get-Volume).DriveLetter + ':'
> Set-Location $drive

^^  this.
It's more obvious with a VHD file than an ISO for a CD/DVD, but the letter is associated with the filesystem not with the disk (which may have multiple filesystems or none)
It's the difference between `get-ciminstance win32_diskDrive` and `get-ciminstance win32_volume`

comments.author: cobalthex

this will not work on linux

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
> this will not work on linux
> 
The mount-diskimage command is not available on linux - or at least not in 6.2 running on WSL which is what I have here. 
On linux, you mount whatever devices and or filesystems you need to with native commands, and CD into them using the path you'd use in any other shell. 

> something also to note, the volume path (\.\Volume{...}) also does not resolve
That's a windows device path not a filesystem path

comments.author: tmeadon
comments.body:
> this will not work on linux

You would still need to supply `Set-Location` with the path the partition you are interested in (as @jhoneill pointed out, there could be multiple partitions on the disk) is mounted in as opposed to the path to the device itself.  It's the difference between `cd /dev/sdb` and `cd /mnt/mydisk`.
